aws::graph::propositions: # Helicopter Fuel System Examination and Pilot Information
The company that repaired the helicopter performed a detailed examination of the fuel system at the request of the National Transportation Safety Board (NTSB) Investigator-in-Charge (IIC).
The fuel system examination found no mechanical deficiencies that would have precluded normal operation of the fuel system and engine.
The fuel gauge was not calibrated correctly.
When 19 pounds of fuel were placed in the fuel tank, the fuel gauge indicated 2 bar widths above the red dot on the gauge.
The red dot on the fuel gauge marks the 35 pounds of fuel level.
When 35 pounds of fuel were placed in the tank, the gauge indicated between the red dot and 100 pounds.
The fuel-low caution light was not calibrated correctly.
The fuel-low caution light should activate when 35 pounds of fuel remain in the tank.
The fuel-low caution light came on at 19 pounds of fuel.
The operator reported the fuel-low caution light was inspected as part of a continuous airworthiness inspection on March 1, 2012.
No maintenance was performed on the fuel quantity sensor system from the time of the March 1, 2012 inspection to the time of the accident.
The pilot held an Airline transport certificate.
The pilot held a Single-engine land airplane rating.
The pilot held a Helicopter aircraft rating.
The pilot held Instrument ratings for Airplane and Helicopter.
The pilot had no Instructor ratings.
The pilot held a Class 2 medical certification with waivers/limitations.
The pilot was an occupational pilot.
The pilot had 7429 total flight hours in all aircraft.
The pilot had 3866 total flight hours in this make and model of aircraft.
The pilot had 7404 Pilot In Command hours in all aircraft.
The pilot had 86 flight hours in the last 90 days in all aircraft.
The pilot had 20 flight hours in the last 30 days in all aircraft.
The pilot had 3 flight hours in the last 24 hours in all aircraft.
The pilot was 46 years old.
The pilot was male.
The pilot occupied the left seat.
No second pilot was present.
No toxicology was performed on the pilot.
The pilot's last FAA medical examination was on August 3, 2012.

text:
# At the request of the National Transportation Safety Board (NTSB) Investigator-in-Charge (IIC), the company that repaired the helicopter performed a more detailed examination of the fuel system and found no mechanical deficiencies that would have precluded normal operation of the fuel system and engine. However, the fuel gauge and fuel-low caution light were not calibrated correctly. When 19 pounds of fuel were placed in the fuel tank, the fuel gauge indicated 2 bar widths above the red dot on the guage (red dot is the 35 pounds of fuel mark); and, when 35 pounds of fuel were placed in the tank, the gauge indicated between the red dot and 100 pounds. The fuel-low caution light, which should come on when 35 pounds of fuel are remaining in the tank, came on at 19 pounds.

According to the operator, the fuel-low caution light was inspected as part of a continuous airworthiness inspection on March 1, 2012. From the time this inspection was completed to the time of the accident, no other maintenance was performed on the fuel quantity sensor system.

## Pilot Information

| Airplane Rating(s): | Single-engine land |

| Medical Certification: | Class 2 With waivers/limitations |
| Occupational Pilot: | Yes |
| Flight Time: | 7429 hours (Total, all aircraft), 3866 hours (Total, this make and model), 7404 hours (Pilot In Command, all aircraft), 86 hours (Last 90 days, all aircraft), 20 hours (Last 30 days, all aircraft), 3 hours (Last 24 hours, all aircraft) |

|-|-|
